data.title: Fix for Issue #917
data.body:
Fix for https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/917

Prevents the OnVisible and OnEnable changed constructors from firing during construction of GameComponents and Drawable game components.

This lines up to the behavior I have observed from other XNA implementations.

data.title: OnVisible/OnEnabled Fire Events During Constructor
data.body:
I've noticed that in the constructor of GameComponent and DrawableGameComponent, the Visible and Enabled properties are set to true explicitly. However, this triggers an extra event to be dispatched and the OnVisible/EnabledChanged methods to be called during object construction.

We have not seen this behavior on other implementations of the XNA API, and it may cause unexpected behavior if applications are not expecting this event at this time. 

It would be nicer if the _visible and _enabled backing fields were set to true instead of the properties themselves.

data.title: Can't load effect
[Linux] Crash during OpenTKGameWindow construction
data.body:
As of 726427f847589fdf9aeed3c251884f2a05d4e8da (latest develop3d at time of writing), I'm getting this exception when running on Linux, right as stuff is starting up. This is new over the past week or so.

```
System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.OpenTKGameWindow.Initialize () [0x0016c] in p:\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Desktop\OpenTKGameWindow.cs:285 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.OpenTKGameWindow..ctor () [0x00013] in p:\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Desktop\OpenTKGameWindow.cs:127 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.OpenTKGamePlatform..ctor (Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game game) [0x00017] in p:\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Desktop\OpenTKGamePlatform.cs:105 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GamePlatform.Create (Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game game) [0x00001] in p:\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\GamePlatform.cs:96 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game..ctor () [0x00206] in p:\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Game.cs:138 
  at Platformer.PlatformerGame..ctor () [0x0008f] in p:\platformer\Platformer.Engine\PlatformerGame.cs:101 
  at Platformer.Program.<Main>b__0 () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Platformer.ExceptionWrapper.Wrap (System.Action action) [0x0001a] in p:\platformer\Platformer.Engine\ExceptionWrapper.cs:25 
```

I think it's a side effect of b5123b9c4c0bf10f79910acaf656c7916e867b74 . The relevant code used to do this:

``` csharp
#if LINUX
    Threading.BackgroundContext.MakeCurrent(Threading.WindowInfo);      
#endif
```

Now it does this:

``` csharp
// Make the foreground context the current context
if (!GraphicsContext.CurrentContext.IsCurrent)
    window.MakeCurrent();
```

On Linux at least, GraphicsContext.CurrentContext is null here. It works just fine on Windows though.

When I put the old #if LINUX code back in, it works, but I suspect it was taken out for a reason!

I'm using the SVN version of OpenTK from the ThirdParty/Libs submodule. I haven't looked into it enough to know if it's an OpenTK bug or an OpenTK usage issue, but SVN OpenTK certainly seems pretty buggy on Linux to me otherwise...

data.title: MGFX: Compiler optimizations break float4x4 parameters
[iOS] Handle is not allocated exception
data.body:
I receive the following exception when the finalizer of RenderTarget is called:

```
{System.InvalidOperationException: Handle is not allocated
at System.Runtime.InteropServices.GCHandle.get_Target () [0x0001b] in /Developer/MonoTouch/Source/mono/mcs/class/corlib/System.Runtime.InteropServices/GCHandle.cs:80
at System.WeakReference.get_Target () [0x00000] in /Developer/MonoTouch/Source/mono/mcs/class/corlib/System/WeakReference.cs:95
at System.WeakReference.get_IsAlive () [0x00000] in /Developer/MonoTouch/Source/mono/mcs/class/corlib/System/WeakReference.cs:88
at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsResource.get_GraphicsDevice () [0x00000] in /Users/turtlegames/Documents/Development/MonoDevelop/ui/MonoGame/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/GraphicsResource.cs:157
at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderTarget2D.Dispose (Boolean disposing) [0x0000b] in /Users/turtlegames/Documents/Development/MonoDevelop/ui/MonoGame/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/RenderTarget2D.cs:184
at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsResource.Finalize () [0x00000] in /Users/turtlegames/Documents/Development/MonoDevelop/ui/MonoGame/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/GraphicsResource.cs:74 }
```

The rendertarget's dispose is called, which checks for the GraphicsDevice. The graphicsdevice seems to be null in GraphicsResource.cs, so it's weakreference IsAlive is called. The Alive property checks for the Target property, which then gets the GCHandle's Target property, which ends up throwing this exception.

data.title: GL ES 2.0 bad performances
data.body:
It seems that MG 3.0 is performing bad than MG 2.0 with GL ES 1.1. 

Forum topic
http://monogame.codeplex.com/discussions/401025

I've prepared as mall test app which test performances of GL ES 1.1 (MG2.0) and GL ES 2.0 (MG 3.0)

you can find here the app

https://dl.dropbox.com/u/40411013/MonoGame/MGPerfTest.zip

The zip contains:
- A simple small app for iOS built with MonoDevelop and MT (You need a valid MT license to deploy to real device). Well commented.
- Our version of MG 2.0 which contains billions of fixes (this makes the MG 2.0 quite stable on iOS and Android ONLY, we currently use this for production)
- The latest version of MG 3.0 (branch3d) downloaded from github

To test performances just run the application (on real device please). To change from MG 2.0 to MG 3.0 just change project reference.

Tests have been made using ARMV7 optimized compilation (no thumb-2) iOS min version is 4.0

Our results are:
- MG 2.0 (GL ES 1.1) on iPhone4 with iOS6, 200 sprites 64x64: 60 FPS
- MG 3.0 (GL ES 2.0) on iPhone4 with iOS6, 200 sprites 64x64: ~44 FPS 

Any help will be appreciated!

Francesco - Ad Maiora Studio

data.title: Fixes to Dispose pattern and disposing GL objects
data.body:
- I believe this addresses all known issues in #883 and #893.
- Fixes the Dispose pattern for many classes.  Allows Dispose() to be called multiple times. Dispose() suppresses the finalizer.  Finalizer calls Dispose() if the developer forgets.
- Fixes GL object disposal so it copes with the GL context going away, the GraphicsDevice being disposed, and disposal on a worker thread.  Dispatches the disposal work to the UI thread, which is then performed during GraphicsDevice.Present().
- Ensure GraphicsDevice.Present() is called consistently amongst platforms.
- Game.EndDraw() now calls Platform.Present().
- Game now disposes Content and GraphicsDeviceManager.
- GraphicsResource.GraphicsDevice is now a WeakReference internally to cope with the GraphicsDevice being garbage collected out of order at shutdown.
- GraphicsResource-derived classes no longer add an event handler to GraphicsDevice.DeviceResetting.  This eliminates a strong reference that was preventing objects from being garbage collected.  Functionality is replaced with the global list of GraphicsResource objects and GraphicsResource.DoGraphicsDeviceResetting().
- There may be some other small fixes in there that I have omitted to mention.

Tested on Windows and Android.

data.title: Fixes sensor delay issues related to blocking main thread
data.body:
After discussion this with xamarin over and over, I think that this is the best workaround we can find.
In general, the issue is that if we do something to block the main thread (like loading content), our sensorchanged events get delayed for a few seconds. Then they will catch up. But in the meantime, it will look something like this:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8UFRDGMIrlw

I also moved the motionmanager to be static across the sensors (another xamarin recommendation).

data.title: Change vertex structs to have StructLayout(LayoutKind.Sequential, Pack=1)
data.body:
I believe all of the following structs ought to have a StructLayout(LayoutKind.Sequential, Pack=1) attribute added:
- VertexPositionColor
- VertexPositionColorTexture
- VertexPositionNormalTexture
- VertexPositionTexture

(I also added it to VertexColorTexture, although now that I look at the code that type doesn't even seem to be used anywhere...)

Without this attribute these structs could potentially be laid out in memory on some platforms in a way that doesn't match their vertex declarations (e.g. with gaps), which will lead to incorrect rendering.

Specifically, I ran into an issue on 64-bit Linux where the "natural" layout of VertexPositionTexture was not the "packed" layout expressed in the vertex declaration. Adding the StructLayout attribute fixes this problem.

data.title: Colored triangle (using vertex colors) renders white
data.body:
I have a simple-to-reproduce case where a simple triangle does not render properly. Here is the source code which can be pasted into a Game class to reproduce the error:

http://pastebin.com/HbW0PVif

This exact code in XNA 4 (on the PC) results in a triangle with the verts being red/green/yellow. On Android (specifically Motoroal Droid Razr) renders the triangle correctly for 1 frame.  The next frame the triangle renders, but it renders white instead of colored.  I suspect something is not being preserved in the states frame-to-frame; however in my investigation of the code it looks like we're using pixel shaders, which I'm not as familiar with in open GL - were it fixed function I may have been able to identify the issue.

Anyway, given the relatively easy repro steps I don't think it'll be hard for those more knowledgeable with OGL to figure out what's going on.
